payload.content: Before setting up OpenClaw, define your threat model by understanding what attackers target in your setup, including malicious skill injection, prompt injection via messages, runaway automation loops, memory poisoning, and credential harvesting from plaintext files.

name: Before setting up OpenClaw, define your threat model by understanding what attac
content: Before setting up OpenClaw, define your threat model by understanding what attackers target in your setup, including malicious skill injection, prompt injection via messages, runaway automation loops, memory poisoning, and credential harvesting from plaintext files.

payload.content: For initial Mac Mini setup for OpenClaw, complete the macOS setup wizard, enable FileVault, connect to Wi-Fi, skip iCloud if dedicated, and install macOS updates. Then, configure system security settings by turning on the Firewall and allowing applications only from the App Store and identified developers.

name: For initial Mac Mini setup for OpenClaw, complete the macOS setup wizard, enable
content: For initial Mac Mini setup for OpenClaw, complete the macOS setup wizard, enable FileVault, connect to Wi-Fi, skip iCloud if dedicated, and install macOS updates. Then, configure system security settings by turning on the Firewall and allowing applications only from the App Store and identified developers.

payload.content: Install Xcode Command Line Tools using `xcode-select --install` and Homebrew using the provided curl command, then add Homebrew to your PATH by running the specified `echo` and `eval` commands.

name: Install Xcode Command Line Tools using `xcode-select --install` and Homebrew usi
content: Install Xcode Command Line Tools using `xcode-select --install` and Homebrew using the provided curl command, then add Homebrew to your PATH by running the specified `echo` and `eval` commands.

payload.content: Install Node.js 22+ using `brew install node@22` and verify its version with `node --version` and `npm --version`. If `node --version` doesn't work, link it with `brew link --overwrite node@22`.

name: Install Node.js 22+ using `brew install node@22` and verify its version with `no
content: Install Node.js 22+ using `brew install node@22` and verify its version with `node --version` and `npm --version`. If `node --version` doesn't work, link it with `brew link --overwrite node@22`.

payload.content: Install Git using `brew install git` and verify its installation with `git --version`.

name: Install Git using `brew install git` and verify its installation with `git --ver
content: Install Git using `brew install git` and verify its installation with `git --version`.

payload.content: Install Docker Desktop using `brew install --cask docker`, then open and complete its setup, ensuring it is running for sandboxing functionality.

name: Install Docker Desktop using `brew install --cask docker`, then open and complet
content: Install Docker Desktop using `brew install --cask docker`, then open and complete its setup, ensuring it is running for sandboxing functionality.

payload.content: Install OpenClaw by running the official installer script `curl -fsSL https://openclaw.ai/install.sh | bash`.

name: Install OpenClaw by running the official installer script `curl -fsSL https://op
content: Install OpenClaw by running the official installer script `curl -fsSL https://openclaw.ai/install.sh | bash`.

payload.content: Verify OpenClaw's version using `openclaw --version` and ensure it is 2026.2.9 or higher to avoid vulnerability to CVE-2026-25253; if lower, update immediately with `openclaw update`.

name: Verify OpenClaw's version using `openclaw --version` and ensure it is 2026.2.9 o
content: Verify OpenClaw's version using `openclaw --version` and ensure it is 2026.2.9 or higher to avoid vulnerability to CVE-2026-25253; if lower, update immediately with `openclaw update`.

payload.content: Verify OpenClaw installation health using `openclaw doctor` and resolve any flagged issues before proceeding.

name: Verify OpenClaw installation health using `openclaw doctor` and resolve any flag
content: Verify OpenClaw installation health using `openclaw doctor` and resolve any flagged issues before proceeding.

payload.content: For OpenClaw authentication, create API keys for Moonshot AI (Kimi K2.5) and Anthropic (Claude Sonnet 4.5), adding $5-10 credit to each, and save them securely.

name: For OpenClaw authentication, create API keys for Moonshot AI (Kimi K2.5) and Ant
content: For OpenClaw authentication, create API keys for Moonshot AI (Kimi K2.5) and Anthropic (Claude Sonnet 4.5), adding $5-10 credit to each, and save them securely.

payload.content: During the OpenClaw onboarding wizard, select Moonshot AI Kimi K2.5 as the primary model, using the international endpoint, and paste your Moonshot API key when prompted.

name: During the OpenClaw onboarding wizard, select Moonshot AI Kimi K2.5 as the prima
content: During the OpenClaw onboarding wizard, select Moonshot AI Kimi K2.5 as the primary model, using the international endpoint, and paste your Moonshot API key when prompted.

payload.content: Configure OpenClaw gateway settings to `local` mode, bind to `127.0.0.1` (localhost only), use port `18789`, and set a strong, long (20+ characters) random password for authentication using `openclaw config set gateway.auth.password "YOUR_STRONG_PASSWORD_HERE"`, storing it in a password manager.

name: Configure OpenClaw gateway settings to `local` mode, bind to `127.0.0.1` (localh
content: Configure OpenClaw gateway settings to `local` mode, bind to `127.0.0.1` (localhost only), use port `18789`, and set a strong, long (20+ characters) random password for authentication using `openclaw config set gateway.auth.password "YOUR_STRONG_PASSWORD_HERE"`, storing it in a password manager.

payload.content: After OpenClaw onboarding, add Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 as a fallback model by first adding your Anthropic API key with `openclaw models auth add`, then adding Sonnet as a fallback with `openclaw models fallbacks add anthropic/claude-sonnet-4-5`, and finally registering an alias for easy switching.

name: After OpenClaw onboarding, add Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 as a fallback model b
content: After OpenClaw onboarding, add Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 as a fallback model by first adding your Anthropic API key with `openclaw models auth add`, then adding Sonnet as a fallback with `openclaw models fallbacks add anthropic/claude-sonnet-4-5`, and finally registering an alias for easy switching.

payload.content: To configure Kimi K2.5 as the primary model in OpenClaw, select Moonshot AI Kimi K2.5, provide your Kimi API key, and the wizard will automatically configure it.

name: To configure Kimi K2.5 as the primary model in OpenClaw, select Moonshot AI Kimi
content: To configure Kimi K2.5 as the primary model in OpenClaw, select Moonshot AI Kimi K2.5, provide your Kimi API key, and the wizard will automatically configure it.

payload.content: To add Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 as a fallback model in OpenClaw, first add your Anthropic API key using `openclaw models auth add`, then add Sonnet as a fallback with `openclaw models fallbacks add anthropic/claude-sonnet-4-5`, and register aliases for easy switching using `openclaw config set agents.defaults.models`.

name: To add Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 as a fallback model in OpenClaw, first add yo
content: To add Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 as a fallback model in OpenClaw, first add your Anthropic API key using `openclaw models auth add`, then add Sonnet as a fallback with `openclaw models fallbacks add anthropic/claude-sonnet-4-5`, and register aliases for easy switching using `openclaw config set agents.defaults.models`.

payload.content: Verify OpenClaw model configuration by running `openclaw models status` to confirm Kimi K2.5 as primary and Claude Sonnet 4.5 as fallback, then restart the gateway with `openclaw gateway restart`.

name: Verify OpenClaw model configuration by running `openclaw models status` to confi
content: Verify OpenClaw model configuration by running `openclaw models status` to confirm Kimi K2.5 as primary and Claude Sonnet 4.5 as fallback, then restart the gateway with `openclaw gateway restart`.

payload.content: Switch models mid-conversation in Telegram by using `/model sonnet` for Claude Sonnet 4.5, `/model kimi` for Kimi K2.5, and `/model status` to check the current model.

name: Switch models mid-conversation in Telegram by using `/model sonnet` for Claude S
content: Switch models mid-conversation in Telegram by using `/model sonnet` for Claude Sonnet 4.5, `/model kimi` for Kimi K2.5, and `/model status` to check the current model.

payload.content: Using Kimi K2.5 with Claude Sonnet 4.5 as a fallback can reduce estimated monthly costs to $5–20, down from $50–150 with Opus 4.6.

name: Using Kimi K2.5 with Claude Sonnet 4.5 as a fallback can reduce estimated monthl
content: Using Kimi K2.5 with Claude Sonnet 4.5 as a fallback can reduce estimated monthly costs to $5–20, down from $50–150 with Opus 4.6.

payload.content: To create a Telegram bot for OpenClaw, search for `@BotFather` in Telegram, send `/newbot`, follow the prompts to name and username the bot, and save the provided token.

name: To create a Telegram bot for OpenClaw, search for `@BotFather` in Telegram, send
content: To create a Telegram bot for OpenClaw, search for `@BotFather` in Telegram, send `/newbot`, follow the prompts to name and username the bot, and save the provided token.

payload.content: Configure optional BotFather settings for your Telegram bot by sending `/setjoingroups` and disabling it, and sending `/setprivacy` and enabling it to limit group interactions.

name: Configure optional BotFather settings for your Telegram bot by sending `/setjoin
content: Configure optional BotFather settings for your Telegram bot by sending `/setjoingroups` and disabling it, and sending `/setprivacy` and enabling it to limit group interactions.

payload.content: Configure Telegram in OpenClaw by setting `channels.telegram.enabled` to `true`, `channels.telegram.botToken` to your bot's token, `channels.telegram.dmPolicy` to `pairing`, and `channels.telegram.configWrites` to `false`.

name: Configure Telegram in OpenClaw by setting `channels.telegram.enabled` to `true`,
content: Configure Telegram in OpenClaw by setting `channels.telegram.enabled` to `true`, `channels.telegram.botToken` to your bot's token, `channels.telegram.dmPolicy` to `pairing`, and `channels.telegram.configWrites` to `false`.

payload.content: `dmPolicy: "pairing"` in OpenClaw's Telegram configuration means strangers cannot message your bot directly; they receive a pairing code that requires approval.

name: `dmPolicy: "pairing"` in OpenClaw's Telegram configuration means strangers canno
content: `dmPolicy: "pairing"` in OpenClaw's Telegram configuration means strangers cannot message your bot directly; they receive a pairing code that requires approval.

payload.content: `configWrites: false` in OpenClaw's Telegram configuration prevents anyone from changing your OpenClaw configuration through Telegram messages.

name: `configWrites: false` in OpenClaw's Telegram configuration prevents anyone from
content: `configWrites: false` in OpenClaw's Telegram configuration prevents anyone from changing your OpenClaw configuration through Telegram messages.

payload.content: Disable group chat for your OpenClaw Telegram bot by setting `channels.telegram.groupPolicy` to `disabled` to prevent random groups from triggering your agent.

name: Disable group chat for your OpenClaw Telegram bot by setting `channels.telegram.
content: Disable group chat for your OpenClaw Telegram bot by setting `channels.telegram.groupPolicy` to `disabled` to prevent random groups from triggering your agent.

payload.content: Restart the OpenClaw gateway after configuration changes using `openclaw gateway restart`.

name: Restart the OpenClaw gateway after configuration changes using `openclaw gateway
content: Restart the OpenClaw gateway after configuration changes using `openclaw gateway restart`.

payload.content: To pair your Telegram account with OpenClaw, message your bot, receive a pairing code, and approve it using `openclaw pairing approve telegram <CODE>` or via the Control UI.

name: To pair your Telegram account with OpenClaw, message your bot, receive a pairing
content: To pair your Telegram account with OpenClaw, message your bot, receive a pairing code, and approve it using `openclaw pairing approve telegram <CODE>` or via the Control UI.

payload.content: Test basic conversation with your OpenClaw bot by sending messages like "What model are you running?" or "What's your current version?" on Telegram.

name: Test basic conversation with your OpenClaw bot by sending messages like "What mo
content: Test basic conversation with your OpenClaw bot by sending messages like "What model are you running?" or "What's your current version?" on Telegram.

payload.content: If the OpenClaw bot responds with Claude Sonnet instead of Kimi K2.5, debug by checking model routing and running `openclaw models status`.

name: If the OpenClaw bot responds with Claude Sonnet instead of Kimi K2.5, debug by c
content: If the OpenClaw bot responds with Claude Sonnet instead of Kimi K2.5, debug by checking model routing and running `openclaw models status`.

payload.content: Run a security audit in OpenClaw using `openclaw security audit` to identify and fix findings, such as setting a gateway password, configuring `dmPolicy` to `pairing`, or binding the gateway to `127.0.0.1`.

name: Run a security audit in OpenClaw using `openclaw security audit` to identify and
content: Run a security audit in OpenClaw using `openclaw security audit` to identify and fix findings, such as setting a gateway password, configuring `dmPolicy` to `pairing`, or binding the gateway to `127.0.0.1`.

payload.content: Automatically fix security issues in OpenClaw by running `openclaw security audit --fix`, which tightens safe defaults and fixes file permissions.

name: Automatically fix security issues in OpenClaw by running `openclaw security audi
content: Automatically fix security issues in OpenClaw by running `openclaw security audit --fix`, which tightens safe defaults and fixes file permissions.

payload.content: Verify that there are no critical security findings after applying fixes by running `openclaw security audit` again.

name: Verify that there are no critical security findings after applying fixes by runn
content: Verify that there are no critical security findings after applying fixes by running `openclaw security audit` again.

payload.content: The Docker sandbox in OpenClaw runs the agent's tool execution (shell commands, file operations) inside isolated Docker containers to limit the blast radius if the agent is tricked into malicious actions.

name: The Docker sandbox in OpenClaw runs the agent's tool execution (shell commands,
content: The Docker sandbox in OpenClaw runs the agent's tool execution (shell commands, file operations) inside isolated Docker containers to limit the blast radius if the agent is tricked into malicious actions.

payload.content: Ensure Docker is running by opening Docker Desktop and verifying with `docker info` before building the OpenClaw sandbox image.

name: Ensure Docker is running by opening Docker Desktop and verifying with `docker in
content: Ensure Docker is running by opening Docker Desktop and verifying with `docker info` before building the OpenClaw sandbox image.

payload.content: Build the OpenClaw sandbox image by navigating to the OpenClaw install directory and running `openclaw sandbox recreate --all` or `$OPENCLAW_DIR/scripts/sandbox-setup.sh`.

name: Build the OpenClaw sandbox image by navigating to the OpenClaw install directory
content: Build the OpenClaw sandbox image by navigating to the OpenClaw install directory and running `openclaw sandbox recreate --all` or `$OPENCLAW_DIR/scripts/sandbox-setup.sh`.

payload.content: Enable sandboxing in OpenClaw by setting `agents.defaults.sandbox.mode` to `all`, `agents.defaults.sandbox.scope` to `session`, and `agents.defaults.sandbox.workspaceAccess` to `ro`.

name: Enable sandboxing in OpenClaw by setting `agents.defaults.sandbox.mode` to `all`
content: Enable sandboxing in OpenClaw by setting `agents.defaults.sandbox.mode` to `all`, `agents.defaults.sandbox.scope` to `session`, and `agents.defaults.sandbox.workspaceAccess` to `ro`.

payload.content: `mode: "all"` for OpenClaw sandboxing means all sessions, including the main DM session, run in Docker containers.

name: `mode: "all"` for OpenClaw sandboxing means all sessions, including the main DM
content: `mode: "all"` for OpenClaw sandboxing means all sessions, including the main DM session, run in Docker containers.

payload.content: `scope: "session"` for OpenClaw sandboxing means each session gets its own isolated Docker container.

name: `scope: "session"` for OpenClaw sandboxing means each session gets its own isola
content: `scope: "session"` for OpenClaw sandboxing means each session gets its own isolated Docker container.

payload.content: `workspaceAccess: "ro"` for OpenClaw sandboxing means the agent can read the workspace but cannot write to it from within the sandbox.

name: `workspaceAccess: "ro"` for OpenClaw sandboxing means the agent can read the wor
content: `workspaceAccess: "ro"` for OpenClaw sandboxing means the agent can read the workspace but cannot write to it from within the sandbox.

payload.content: Isolate the sandbox network in OpenClaw by setting `agents.defaults.sandbox.docker.network` to `none`, which prevents sandbox containers from having internet access.

name: Isolate the sandbox network in OpenClaw by setting `agents.defaults.sandbox.dock
content: Isolate the sandbox network in OpenClaw by setting `agents.defaults.sandbox.docker.network` to `none`, which prevents sandbox containers from having internet access.

payload.content: Set resource limits for OpenClaw sandbox Docker containers by configuring `agents.defaults.sandbox.docker.memory` to "512m", `agents.defaults.sandbox.docker.cpus` to 1, and `agents.defaults.sandbox.docker.pidsLimit` to 100.

name: Set resource limits for OpenClaw sandbox Docker containers by configuring `agent
content: Set resource limits for OpenClaw sandbox Docker containers by configuring `agents.defaults.sandbox.docker.memory` to "512m", `agents.defaults.sandbox.docker.cpus` to 1, and `agents.defaults.sandbox.docker.pidsLimit` to 100.

payload.content: Restart the OpenClaw gateway and verify sandbox configuration using `openclaw gateway restart` and `openclaw sandbox explain`.

name: Restart the OpenClaw gateway and verify sandbox configuration using `openclaw ga
content: Restart the OpenClaw gateway and verify sandbox configuration using `openclaw gateway restart` and `openclaw sandbox explain`.

payload.content: Tool policy in OpenClaw controls which tools the agent can use, even within the sandbox, to restrict available functionalities.

name: Tool policy in OpenClaw controls which tools the agent can use, even within the
content: Tool policy in OpenClaw controls which tools the agent can use, even within the sandbox, to restrict available functionalities.

payload.content: Deny dangerous tools in OpenClaw by setting `tools.deny` to `["browser", "exec", "process", "apply_patch", "write", "edit"]` to prevent web browsing, shell command execution, process management, file patching, and file system modifications.

name: Deny dangerous tools in OpenClaw by setting `tools.deny` to `["browser", "exec",
content: Deny dangerous tools in OpenClaw by setting `tools.deny` to `["browser", "exec", "process", "apply_patch", "write", "edit"]` to prevent web browsing, shell command execution, process management, file patching, and file system modifications.

payload.content: With the specified deny list, an OpenClaw agent can still chat, read files (read-only), use built-in web_search and web_fetch, and utilize sessions and memory tools.

name: With the specified deny list, an OpenClaw agent can still chat, read files (read
content: With the specified deny list, an OpenClaw agent can still chat, read files (read-only), use built-in web_search and web_fetch, and utilize sessions and memory tools.

payload.content: Gradually enable tools in OpenClaw as needed after initial security hardening.

name: Gradually enable tools in OpenClaw as needed after initial security hardening.
content: Gradually enable tools in OpenClaw as needed after initial security hardening.

payload.content: To restrict which tools an agent can use, even within a sandbox, configure a deny list for dangerous tools.

name: To restrict which tools an agent can use, even within a sandbox, configure a den
content: To restrict which tools an agent can use, even within a sandbox, configure a deny list for dangerous tools.

payload.content: To deny dangerous tools like `browser`, `exec`, `process`, `apply_patch`, `write`, and `edit` in OpenClaw, use the command `openclaw config set tools.deny '["browser", "exec", "process", "apply_patch", "write", "edit"]'`.

name: To deny dangerous tools like `browser`, `exec`, `process`, `apply_patch`, `write
content: To deny dangerous tools like `browser`, `exec`, `process`, `apply_patch`, `write`, and `edit` in OpenClaw, use the command `openclaw config set tools.deny '["browser", "exec", "process", "apply_patch", "write", "edit"]'`.

payload.content: Denying the `browser` tool prevents the agent from autonomous web browsing, mitigating prompt injection risks from web content.

name: Denying the `browser` tool prevents the agent from autonomous web browsing, miti
content: Denying the `browser` tool prevents the agent from autonomous web browsing, mitigating prompt injection risks from web content.

payload.content: Denying the `exec` tool prevents shell command execution by the agent.

name: Denying the `exec` tool prevents shell command execution by the agent.
content: Denying the `exec` tool prevents shell command execution by the agent.

payload.content: Denying the `process` tool prevents background process management by the agent.

name: Denying the `process` tool prevents background process management by the agent.
content: Denying the `process` tool prevents background process management by the agent.

payload.content: Denying the `apply_patch` tool prevents file patching by the agent.

name: Denying the `apply_patch` tool prevents file patching by the agent.
content: Denying the `apply_patch` tool prevents file patching by the agent.

payload.content: Denying `write` and `edit` tools prevents file system modifications by the agent.

name: Denying `write` and `edit` tools prevents file system modifications by the agent
content: Denying `write` and `edit` tools prevents file system modifications by the agent.

payload.content: To selectively re-enable tools in OpenClaw, use `openclaw config set tools.allow` with a list of desired tools, for example, `openclaw config set tools.allow '["read", "web_search", "web_fetch", "sessions_list", "sessions_history"]'`.

name: To selectively re-enable tools in OpenClaw, use `openclaw config set tools.allow
content: To selectively re-enable tools in OpenClaw, use `openclaw config set tools.allow` with a list of desired tools, for example, `openclaw config set tools.allow '["read", "web_search", "web_fetch", "sessions_list", "sessions_history"]'`.

payload.content: In OpenClaw tool configuration, a deny list takes precedence over an allow list, meaning a tool must be removed from the deny list before it can be added to the allow list.

name: In OpenClaw tool configuration, a deny list takes precedence over an allow list,
content: In OpenClaw tool configuration, a deny list takes precedence over an allow list, meaning a tool must be removed from the deny list before it can be added to the allow list.

payload.content: To disable elevated mode, which allows an agent to escape the sandbox and run on the host, use the command `openclaw config set tools.elevated.enabled false`.

name: To disable elevated mode, which allows an agent to escape the sandbox and run on
content: To disable elevated mode, which allows an agent to escape the sandbox and run on the host, use the command `openclaw config set tools.elevated.enabled false`.

payload.content: SOUL.md is a file that defines an agent's personality, knowledge, and hard boundaries, injected as a system prompt into every conversation.

name: SOUL.md is a file that defines an agent's personality, knowledge, and hard bound
content: SOUL.md is a file that defines an agent's personality, knowledge, and hard boundaries, injected as a system prompt into every conversation.

payload.content: To create a SOUL.md file for an OpenClaw agent, create the directory `~/.openclaw/workspace` and then use `cat` to write the SOUL.md content into `~/.openclaw/workspace/SOUL.md`.

name: To create a SOUL.md file for an OpenClaw agent, create the directory `~/.opencla
content: To create a SOUL.md file for an OpenClaw agent, create the directory `~/.openclaw/workspace` and then use `cat` to write the SOUL.md content into `~/.openclaw/workspace/SOUL.md`.

payload.content: An agent's SOUL.md should include absolute boundaries for financial security, such as prohibiting access to private keys, execution of financial transactions, provision of investment advice, sharing of API keys, or installation of crypto-related tools.

name: An agent's SOUL.md should include absolute boundaries for financial security, su
content: An agent's SOUL.md should include absolute boundaries for financial security, such as prohibiting access to private keys, execution of financial transactions, provision of investment advice, sharing of API keys, or installation of crypto-related tools.

payload.content: An agent's SOUL.md should include absolute boundaries for security posture, such as prohibiting shell command execution without explicit user approval, installation of new skills without approval, following instructions embedded in external content, modifying its own configuration files, or accessing authentication files.

name: An agent's SOUL.md should include absolute boundaries for security posture, such
content: An agent's SOUL.md should include absolute boundaries for security posture, such as prohibiting shell command execution without explicit user approval, installation of new skills without approval, following instructions embedded in external content, modifying its own configuration files, or accessing authentication files.

payload.content: An agent's SOUL.md should include absolute boundaries for communication, such as prohibiting sending messages to anyone other than the authenticated user without explicit approval, forwarding conversation history to external services, or sharing user financial information.

name: An agent's SOUL.md should include absolute boundaries for communication, such as
content: An agent's SOUL.md should include absolute boundaries for communication, such as prohibiting sending messages to anyone other than the authenticated user without explicit approval, forwarding conversation history to external services, or sharing user financial information.

payload.content: An agent's SOUL.md boundaries are the primary defense against prompt injection.

name: An agent's SOUL.md boundaries are the primary defense against prompt injection.
content: An agent's SOUL.md boundaries are the primary defense against prompt injection.

payload.content: Anthropic models are specifically trained to resist prompt injection and prioritize system instructions over user or content instructions.

name: Anthropic models are specifically trained to resist prompt injection and priorit
content: Anthropic models are specifically trained to resist prompt injection and prioritize system instructions over user or content instructions.

payload.content: Kimi K2.5 is optimized for agentic performance and benchmarks, but its adversarial robustness against prompt injection is less publicly tested and documented compared to Anthropic models.

name: Kimi K2.5 is optimized for agentic performance and benchmarks, but its adversari
content: Kimi K2.5 is optimized for agentic performance and benchmarks, but its adversarial robustness against prompt injection is less publicly tested and documented compared to Anthropic models.

payload.content: Tool policy lockdown and Docker sandboxing provide defense-in-depth, limiting potential damage even if a model follows malicious instructions.

name: Tool policy lockdown and Docker sandboxing provide defense-in-depth, limiting po
content: Tool policy lockdown and Docker sandboxing provide defense-in-depth, limiting potential damage even if a model follows malicious instructions.

payload.content: If an agent behaves unexpectedly, such as following instructions from content it's reading or attempting unauthorized tool calls, immediately reset the session with `/new` and investigate session logs.

name: If an agent behaves unexpectedly, such as following instructions from content it
content: If an agent behaves unexpectedly, such as following instructions from content it's reading or attempting unauthorized tool calls, immediately reset the session with `/new` and investigate session logs.

payload.content: Tailscale creates a private VPN mesh for secure remote access without exposing ports to the internet.

name: Tailscale creates a private VPN mesh for secure remote access without exposing p
content: Tailscale creates a private VPN mesh for secure remote access without exposing ports to the internet.

payload.content: To install Tailscale on a Mac, use `brew install --cask tailscale` and then open the application to log in or create an account.

name: To install Tailscale on a Mac, use `brew install --cask tailscale` and then open
content: To install Tailscale on a Mac, use `brew install --cask tailscale` and then open the application to log in or create an account.

payload.content: To verify Tailscale mesh connectivity, run `tailscale status` on your Mac Mini and confirm both your Mac Mini and iPhone are listed with Tailscale IPs (100.x.x.x).

name: To verify Tailscale mesh connectivity, run `tailscale status` on your Mac Mini a
content: To verify Tailscale mesh connectivity, run `tailscale status` on your Mac Mini and confirm both your Mac Mini and iPhone are listed with Tailscale IPs (100.x.x.x).

payload.content: To access the Control UI remotely via Tailscale, navigate to `http://100.x.x.x:18789/` in your iPhone's browser, replacing `100.x.x.x` with your Mac Mini's Tailscale IP.

name: To access the Control UI remotely via Tailscale, navigate to `http://100.x.x.x:1
content: To access the Control UI remotely via Tailscale, navigate to `http://100.x.x.x:18789/` in your iPhone's browser, replacing `100.x.x.x` with your Mac Mini's Tailscale IP.

payload.content: To ensure Tailscale access to a gateway bound to 127.0.0.1, the gateway must also listen on the Tailscale interface, potentially requiring adjustment with `openclaw config set gateway.bind "127.0.0.1"`.

name: To ensure Tailscale access to a gateway bound to 127.0.0.1, the gateway must als
content: To ensure Tailscale access to a gateway bound to 127.0.0.1, the gateway must also listen on the Tailscale interface, potentially requiring adjustment with `openclaw config set gateway.bind "127.0.0.1"`.

payload.content: When configuring API spending limits on Moonshot Platform, load $5–10 initially, do not auto-reload, and be aware that Moonshot stops serving requests when credits run out, acting as a natural spending cap.

name: When configuring API spending limits on Moonshot Platform, load $5–10 initially,
content: When configuring API spending limits on Moonshot Platform, load $5–10 initially, do not auto-reload, and be aware that Moonshot stops serving requests when credits run out, acting as a natural spending cap.

payload.content: Moonshot's prepaid credit system provides a safer cost control mechanism than post-paid billing because it physically prevents overspending.

name: Moonshot's prepaid credit system provides a safer cost control mechanism than po
content: Moonshot's prepaid credit system provides a safer cost control mechanism than post-paid billing because it physically prevents overspending.

payload.content: To set API spending limits on Anthropic Console, navigate to Settings → Plans & Billing → Spending Limits, set a monthly limit (e.g., $50/month) and a daily limit (e.g., $5/day), and configure email alerts at 50% and 80% of limits.

name: To set API spending limits on Anthropic Console, navigate to Settings → Plans &
content: To set API spending limits on Anthropic Console, navigate to Settings → Plans & Billing → Spending Limits, set a monthly limit (e.g., $50/month) and a daily limit (e.g., $5/day), and configure email alerts at 50% and 80% of limits.

payload.content: To monitor API usage across Moonshot and Anthropic, use `openclaw status --usage` and regularly check the usage dashboards on platform.moonshot.ai and console.anthropic.com.

name: To monitor API usage across Moonshot and Anthropic, use `openclaw status --usage
content: To monitor API usage across Moonshot and Anthropic, use `openclaw status --usage` and regularly check the usage dashboards on platform.moonshot.ai and console.anthropic.com.

payload.content: To secure sensitive data stored in plaintext by OpenClaw, restrict directory and file permissions using `chmod 700 ~/.openclaw`, `chmod 600 ~/.openclaw/openclaw.json`, and `chmod -R 700 ~/.openclaw/credentials/`.

name: To secure sensitive data stored in plaintext by OpenClaw, restrict directory and
content: To secure sensitive data stored in plaintext by OpenClaw, restrict directory and file permissions using `chmod 700 ~/.openclaw`, `chmod 600 ~/.openclaw/openclaw.json`, and `chmod -R 700 ~/.openclaw/credentials/`.

payload.content: To manage API spending for Anthropic, set a monthly and daily spending limit via their console (Settings → Plans & Billing → Spending Limits). Recommended starting limits are $5/day and $50/month. Configure email alerts for 50% and 80% of limits.

name: To manage API spending for Anthropic, set a monthly and daily spending limit via
content: To manage API spending for Anthropic, set a monthly and daily spending limit via their console (Settings → Plans & Billing → Spending Limits). Recommended starting limits are $5/day and $50/month. Configure email alerts for 50% and 80% of limits.

payload.content: Monitor API usage across Moonshot and Anthropic by using the `openclaw status --usage` command and regularly checking their respective dashboards (Moonshot: platform.moonshot.ai → Console → Usage; Anthropic: console.anthropic.com → Usage tab).

name: Monitor API usage across Moonshot and Anthropic by using the `openclaw status --
content: Monitor API usage across Moonshot and Anthropic by using the `openclaw status --usage` command and regularly checking their respective dashboards (Moonshot: platform.moonshot.ai → Console → Usage; Anthropic: console.anthropic.com → Usage tab).

payload.content: OpenClaw stores sensitive data in plaintext.

name: OpenClaw stores sensitive data in plaintext.
content: OpenClaw stores sensitive data in plaintext.

payload.content: To secure OpenClaw's sensitive plaintext data, restrict file permissions for the `~/.openclaw` directory and its contents to owner-only access using `chmod 700 ~/.openclaw`, `chmod 600 ~/.openclaw/openclaw.json`, and `chmod -R 700 ~/.openclaw/credentials/ ~/.openclaw/agents/`.

name: To secure OpenClaw's sensitive plaintext data, restrict file permissions for the
content: To secure OpenClaw's sensitive plaintext data, restrict file permissions for the `~/.openclaw` directory and its contents to owner-only access using `chmod 700 ~/.openclaw`, `chmod 600 ~/.openclaw/openclaw.json`, and `chmod -R 700 ~/.openclaw/credentials/ ~/.openclaw/agents/`.

payload.content: Verify OpenClaw's LaunchAgent is installed and runs on boot by checking for `bot.molt.gateway.plist` in `~/Library/LaunchAgents/` using `ls ~/Library/LaunchAgents/ | grep -i "molt\|openclaw\|claw"` and confirming it's listed by `launchctl list | grep -i "molt\|openclaw\|claw"`.

name: Verify OpenClaw's LaunchAgent is installed and runs on boot by checking for `bot
content: Verify OpenClaw's LaunchAgent is installed and runs on boot by checking for `bot.molt.gateway.plist` in `~/Library/LaunchAgents/` using `ls ~/Library/LaunchAgents/ | grep -i "molt\|openclaw\|claw"` and confirming it's listed by `launchctl list | grep -i "molt\|openclaw\|claw"`.

payload.content: To ensure 24/7 operation of a Mac Mini running OpenClaw, prevent automatic sleeping by enabling 'Prevent automatic sleeping when the display is off' in System Settings → Energy.

name: To ensure 24/7 operation of a Mac Mini running OpenClaw, prevent automatic sleep
content: To ensure 24/7 operation of a Mac Mini running OpenClaw, prevent automatic sleeping by enabling 'Prevent automatic sleeping when the display is off' in System Settings → Energy.

payload.content: Test OpenClaw's daemon restart functionality by rebooting the Mac Mini (`sudo reboot`) and then verifying the gateway status (`openclaw gateway status`) and sending a test message from Telegram.

name: Test OpenClaw's daemon restart functionality by rebooting the Mac Mini (`sudo re
content: Test OpenClaw's daemon restart functionality by rebooting the Mac Mini (`sudo reboot`) and then verifying the gateway status (`openclaw gateway status`) and sending a test message from Telegram.

payload.content: Matrix provides E2E encrypted messaging, preventing even the server operator from reading messages.

name: Matrix provides E2E encrypted messaging, preventing even the server operator fro
content: Matrix provides E2E encrypted messaging, preventing even the server operator from reading messages.

payload.content: To install the Matrix plugin for OpenClaw, first check its availability with `openclaw plugins list | grep -i matrix`, then install it using `openclaw plugins install @openclaw/matrix` and enable it with `openclaw plugins enable matrix`.

name: To install the Matrix plugin for OpenClaw, first check its availability with `op
content: To install the Matrix plugin for OpenClaw, first check its availability with `openclaw plugins list | grep -i matrix`, then install it using `openclaw plugins install @openclaw/matrix` and enable it with `openclaw plugins enable matrix`.

payload.content: Configure the OpenClaw Matrix channel by setting `channels.matrix.enabled` to `true`, specifying the `homeserver`, `userId`, and `accessToken`, and defining `dmPolicy` and `groupPolicy` using `openclaw config set` commands.

name: Configure the OpenClaw Matrix channel by setting `channels.matrix.enabled` to `t
content: Configure the OpenClaw Matrix channel by setting `channels.matrix.enabled` to `true`, specifying the `homeserver`, `userId`, and `accessToken`, and defining `dmPolicy` and `groupPolicy` using `openclaw config set` commands.

payload.content: Verify the Matrix plugin's E2E encryption status by running `openclaw channels status --probe` and checking the output for the Matrix channel.

name: Verify the Matrix plugin's E2E encryption status by running `openclaw channels s
content: Verify the Matrix plugin's E2E encryption status by running `openclaw channels status --probe` and checking the output for the Matrix channel.

payload.content: To migrate primary agent communication to Matrix, first test with basic conversations, then gradually shift usage, and consider disabling Telegram by setting `channels.telegram.enabled` to `false` and restarting the gateway once Matrix is stable.

name: To migrate primary agent communication to Matrix, first test with basic conversa
content: To migrate primary agent communication to Matrix, first test with basic conversations, then gradually shift usage, and consider disabling Telegram by setting `channels.telegram.enabled` to `false` and restarting the gateway once Matrix is stable.

payload.content: Run `openclaw security audit` weekly to perform regular security audits.

name: Run `openclaw security audit` weekly to perform regular security audits.
content: Run `openclaw security audit` weekly to perform regular security audits.

payload.content: Verify that your OpenClaw gateway is not publicly accessible by attempting to reach your Mac Mini's public IP on port 18789 from another device not on Tailscale using `curl -s --connect-timeout 5 http://YOUR_PUBLIC_IP:18789/`; the connection should fail or timeout.

name: Verify that your OpenClaw gateway is not publicly accessible by attempting to re
content: Verify that your OpenClaw gateway is not publicly accessible by attempting to reach your Mac Mini's public IP on port 18789 from another device not on Tailscale using `curl -s --connect-timeout 5 http://YOUR_PUBLIC_IP:18789/`; the connection should fail or timeout.

payload.content: Rotate API keys and tokens every 3 months for Moonshot, Anthropic, Telegram, gateway auth password, and exchange API keys by generating new ones, updating OpenClaw configuration, and revoking old ones.

name: Rotate API keys and tokens every 3 months for Moonshot, Anthropic, Telegram, gat
content: Rotate API keys and tokens every 3 months for Moonshot, Anthropic, Telegram, gateway auth password, and exchange API keys by generating new ones, updating OpenClaw configuration, and revoking old ones.

payload.content: Monitor API usage with `openclaw status --usage` and investigate immediately if unexpected spikes occur, as they could indicate a runaway loop or compromised agent.

name: Monitor API usage with `openclaw status --usage` and investigate immediately if
content: Monitor API usage with `openclaw status --usage` and investigate immediately if unexpected spikes occur, as they could indicate a runaway loop or compromised agent.

payload.content: If a compromise is suspected, immediately stop the gateway (`openclaw gateway stop`), revoke all connected credentials (Moonshot, Anthropic, Telegram, Matrix), check for unauthorized processes (`ps aux | grep -i "openclaw\|node\|curl\|wget"`), review recent session logs for suspicious activity, and check for unauthorized file modifications (`find ~ -newer ~/.openclaw/openclaw.json -name "*.sh" -o -name "*.py" 2>/dev/null`).

name: If a compromise is suspected, immediately stop the gateway (`openclaw gateway st
content: If a compromise is suspected, immediately stop the gateway (`openclaw gateway stop`), revoke all connected credentials (Moonshot, Anthropic, Telegram, Matrix), check for unauthorized processes (`ps aux | grep -i "openclaw\|node\|curl\|wget"`), review recent session logs for suspicious activity, and check for unauthorized file modifications (`find ~ -newer ~/.openclaw/openclaw.json -name "*.sh" -o -name "*.py" 2>/dev/null`).

payload.content: If a compromise is confirmed, change all passwords (Apple ID, email, exchanges), format the Mac Mini and reinstall from scratch, and consider all stored credentials and data the agent could read as fully compromised.

name: If a compromise is confirmed, change all passwords (Apple ID, email, exchanges),
content: If a compromise is confirmed, change all passwords (Apple ID, email, exchanges), format the Mac Mini and reinstall from scratch, and consider all stored credentials and data the agent could read as fully compromised.

payload.content: If an API bill is unexpectedly high, stop the gateway (`openclaw gateway stop`), check both Moonshot and Anthropic dashboards for usage breakdowns, review session logs for loops or excessive tool use, lower spending limits, and restart with a restricted tool policy.

name: If an API bill is unexpectedly high, stop the gateway (`openclaw gateway stop`),
content: If an API bill is unexpectedly high, stop the gateway (`openclaw gateway stop`), check both Moonshot and Anthropic dashboards for usage breakdowns, review session logs for loops or excessive tool use, lower spending limits, and restart with a restricted tool policy.

payload.content: If an agent behaves erratically, reset the session by sending `/new` in Telegram or using `openclaw sessions send --target <session_key> --message "/new"`.

name: If an agent behaves erratically, reset the session by sending `/new` in Telegram
content: If an agent behaves erratically, reset the session by sending `/new` in Telegram or using `openclaw sessions send --target <session_key> --message "/new"`.

payload.content: As a 'nuclear option' for an erratically behaving agent, stop the gateway (`openclaw gateway stop`), remove all agent state (`rm -rf ~/.openclaw/agents/*/sessions/*`), and then restart the gateway (`openclaw gateway start`).

name: As a 'nuclear option' for an erratically behaving agent, stop the gateway (`open
content: As a 'nuclear option' for an erratically behaving agent, stop the gateway (`openclaw gateway stop`), remove all agent state (`rm -rf ~/.openclaw/agents/*/sessions/*`), and then restart the gateway (`openclaw gateway start`).
